newsitem.title: NETHERLANDS: FORECAST - Fortis interim profit seen up strongly.
newsitem.headline: FORECAST - Fortis interim profit seen up strongly.

text.p: Dutch-Belgian financial services group Fortis is expected to report a net profit rise of between 13 and 23 percent on Thursday, analysts said.
Fortis, equally-owned by Fortis Amev and Fortis AG, is estimated to report a net profit of between 341 million and 371 million ecus.
First quarter profit jumped 29 percent to 157 million ecus.

Analyst Daan Worm of ING Barings, expecting only a 2.4 percent profit rise in the second quarter, said the quarterly results were likely to follow a peculiar pattern as Fortis includes heavily fluctuating capital gains in its results.
Worm added he estimated that the third quarter would show a 11 percent lower profit compared to the same period in 1995 but final quarter results were expected to surge by 37 percent.
"The biggest rise is expected in the fourth quarter," he said, adding that fourth quarter 1995 results were hit by losses in Belgian and U.S. health insurance.
But analysts said cost reduction schemes had a positive effect on the group's profits.
Harry Luchtenveld of Generale Bank said Dutch-based Fortis Amev was expected to show a profit rise of 15 percent to 390 million guilders in the first-half of 1996.
"The cost reduction scheme are counting for about 10 percent of the 15 percent profit rise expected," Luchtenveld said.
He added that the schemes would have a positive effect on profits in 1997 as well.
The consensus of seven analysts polled by Reuters on the first-half profit of Fortis Amev was set at 386.3 million guilders versus 334.5 million in the same period of 1995.
Banking is expected to post the biggest rise in the first six months and second quarter.
"Volume in the banking sector has increased and the margin is probably higher," said Ton Mulder of NibStrating.
Mulder said the group was also doing good business in the life insurance sector.
"As the trend in life-insurance is strong all over, it's also good for Fortis," he said.
He added that business in the health sector in the United States was probably still tough.
